awd_titl_txt: Novel Computational Mathematics for Aperiodic Multilayers
awd_abstract_narration:
The recent discovery of a whole family of atomically thin layers has led to much interest in the fields of materials science and nanotechnology. In principle, many desired electronic, optical, and thermal material properties can be obtained by stacking vertically a number of such layers to form so-called two-dimensional weakly-bonded integrated multilayers. Such structures are generally non-periodic. This leads to interesting geometrical properties such as moire patterns, but also results in the breakdown of the traditional (periodic) description of materials that is essential to the computer simulation of materials from first principles. The broad goal of this project is to exploit the mathematical structure that arises in quantum models of two-dimensional multilayer materials to enable the efficient and reliable predictions by computer simulations that are required to explore the vast range of design possibilities and to guide or validate experimental studies.

This project aims to develop and analyze novel discretization techniques and algorithms based on the C*-algebra formulation of the quantum electronic transport phenomena. This novel class of numerical techniques will implement directly the noncommutative framework for aperiodic multilayer geometries and enable fast and robust ab-initio computations of electronic properties in two-dimensional multilayer materials. Numerical analysis and theory-based numerical experiments will be developed to optimize and certify the resulting computations. Beyond the case of two-dimensional weakly-bonded integrated multilayers, this new prediction and design tool will also allow the investigation of mechanical or photonic meta-materials by engineering artificial incommensurate geometries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many important future nanotechnologies such as nanoscale sensors, novel electronic components with lower energy consumption are expected to derive from recent advances in design of layered structures obtained by stacking two-dimensional, few-atom thick stable crystals such as graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, transition metal dichalcogenides and many others that have been realized experimentally. The numerical methods developed in this project improve the capability to simulate and understand key atomic-scale physics that govern the atomic elastic relaxation and electronic structure properties of such two-dimensional van der Waals heterostructures.

The major outcome of this project was the development of custom models and simulation methods for incommensurate structures, which generically lack the periodicity forming the basis of traditional simulation techniques. Numerical analysis and theory-based numerical test cases were used to develop the most accurate and efficient approaches, based on the configuration space parameterization: in particular, studies of the atomic relaxation of twisted bilayer as well as trilayer structures and its impact on the electronic structure using coarse-grained continuum modeling with atomistic accuracy, and comparisons with experimental observations.

As prototypical condensed matter systems, two-dimensional materials were an ideal fit to introduce undergraduates and graduate students to the challenges of modeling condensed matter systems, in particular electronic structure computations, topological insulators, and other problems of interest in contemporary nanoscale science and engineering. The PI developed courses, organized seminars and supervised thesis research at the undergraduate and graduate level that taught students mathematical and computational elements that will enable them to contribute to the solution complex scientific problems involving interesting geometries and long-time dynamics combining into a multiscale emergent behavior. This research program naturally led students to study atomistic as well as continuum approaches, to question the assumptions behind simplified models for complex systems, and to learn problem-solving techniques applicable throughout science and engineering.
